Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The inverse problem for thin film properties is a challenge for nanotechnology engineering. We propose the application of a simple and intuitive numerical scheme: a basic particle swarm optimization (PSO) method, to solve the inverse problem from surface plasmon resonance (SPR) experimental results. The purpose is to retrieve unknown parameters from the measurement of the fall in reflectivity due to the excitation of a surface plasmon polariton at a metal/dielectric interface. In this case, the PSO results reveal the possibility of fully exploring the measurement results of experimental angular exploration of the reflectivity by multilayers.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Thin films are very common in biochemistry and physics. For example, they are widely used in semiconductor technologies, spectroscopy, plasmonics, nanophotonics, and optics in general (e.g., antireflection coatings, filters, and semitransparent mirrors). It is therefore of great importance to accurately know their optical properties and thicknesses, on which their attractive properties depend. Measuring thin film properties is an old issue, and a large volume of literature has been published on this subject. The number of physical parameters to be determined (imaginary and real part of the permittivity, thickness) sets the numbers of photonic states of the probe light used in traditional methods (polarization, incidence angle, wavelength, number of measurements). For example, ellipsometry is based on the measure of the reflectance for two different polarizations under oblique incidence [1–3], but the method can encounter difficulties for very thin metallic films because of anisotropy [4, 5]. Spectral reflectometry makes the most of the reflectance for a large spectral range and uses the Kramers–Kronig relation [4, 6, 7]. Note that reflectance measurements do not ensure the uniqueness of the solution [8, 9]. The optical properties and thicknesses of smooth thin films can also be deduced from transmission measurements [10–12] and with a surface plasmon resonance (SPR) setup [13–16] if the multilayers can support surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs). As noted by the authors of Ref. [16], “Unfortunately, these parameters can only be extracted from the experimental data provided by SPR measurements in an indirect way only that requires a subsequent mathematical processing of the results. Difficulties encountered when using this approach are similar to that when treating the ellipsometric data.” Some knowledge about the optical properties or about the thickness is generally necessary to recover the unknown data. The “mathematical processing” is actually a method of experimental data fitting by a model. The search of the best parameters of the model corresponds to finding the minimum of the least-square distance between the fit and the experimental data, also called the fitness function. Therefore, optimization methods could be used to solve this inverse problem. In Ref. [16], the Nelder–Mead optimization algorithm was used [17]. But this method is not bounded and is only able to minimize valley-shaped fitness functions. Like the simulated annealing method [18], it requires a starting value of the parameters that is close to the searched minimum. Since 1999, the increasing development of optimization methods for the design of structures in engineering [19] has enabled the selection of a competitive method for solving the problem of recovering the optical properties and the thicknesses of multilayers from SPR measurements.

The measurement of the optical parameters and thicknesses of a multilayered settlement of metals and dielectrics may appear more tedious as the number of parameters to be recovered is three times the number of layers (the thickness and the real and imaginary parts of the optical index or of the relative permittivity) [20].

In this paper, a single SPR angular interrogation curve at a fixed wavelength [21] is used to solve the inverse problem for a three-layer system. Section 2 describes the SPR setup. To recover thicknesses and optical properties from fitting of the experimental data, the particle swarm optimization (PSO) method and a multilayer model for reflectivity are used (Sect. 3). The effectiveness of the method in terms of uniqueness of the solution is verified using a measurement to another wavelength (Sect. 4). Whatever the probe wavelength, the recovered thicknesses must be the same. Section 5 is devoted to an application of the method to three samples with different thicknesses of the last layer.

Section1.Heading: The Surface Plasmon Resonance setup
Section1.Para: The surface plasmon polariton (SPP) and the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) are fully described in [22] and in a recent paper through mathematical considerations [23]. The SPP is a proof of the sometimes strong coupling between light and matter [24]. From a theoretical point of view, the SPP is a pole of a scattering matrix, and the vanishing of reflectance is related to its residue [23]. The full historical insight and theory are given in [25] where the contributions by Otto and Kretschmann are described and applications of SPPs are given, in particular the detection of low concentrations of biological molecules with an SPR setup. The SPR biosensor is based on the sensitivity of the SPP to the change of optical properties. The reflectance dip is shifted by a small change of relative permittivity of the surrounding medium due to a variation of concentration of the biomolecules of interest [21]. However, the process of fabricating such a biosensor is subject to uncertainties on the thickness of materials used for the active part of the sensor. Moreover, the optical properties of thin layers of metals vary with the thickness and the mode of deposition. Therefore, the optimal tuning of the sensor takes advantage of the knowledge of the true thicknesses and optical properties of the involved layers.

Therefore, we propose to investigate the inverse problem for the reflectance measurement of multilayers in the SPR configuration to determine the unknown experimental parameters. The SPR setup is depicted in Fig. 1. It is based on the Kretschmann configuration [25, 26], where (p) polarized light undergoes total internal reflection (TIR) at a glass/metal-films/air interface.
Fig. 1
Experimental setup used for the measurement of reflectance R as a function of the angle of incidence of illumination θ

The sample holder is a BK7 cylindrical lens, and the optical contact with the sample (microscope slide with multilayers deposited on it) is ensured by the use of a refractive index matching liquid. The vergence of the plano-convex lens is compensated by a microscope objective so that the laser beam incident on the sample is parallel and the incidence angle θ is well defined. This last one can be tuned, due to a rotation stage, in order to excite the SPR. The resonance occurs when the momentum of the incoming light is equal to the momentum of the surface plasmon, and this momentum can be adjusted by varying θ (the SPR occurs above the critical angle for TIR and leads to a sharp dip in the reflectivity).

The optical alignment is done by autocollimation; it is an easy but crucial task in order to accurately measure the angle of incidence and then the SPR location. First, the axis of the cylindrical lens must coincide with the rotation stage axis; second, the incidence point must be on this axis so that the incident ray beam is along a radius of the cylindrical lens (and consequently the refraction angle at the spherical air/BK7 interface is null, which ensures a direct measurement of the incident angle θ on the sample).

Once the alignment is correct, a polarizer allows one to choose the incident (p) polarization and a 50:50 beamsplitter divides the incident light in two: 50 % of the light is turned toward a first photodiode (reference signal), and 50 % is sent toward the metallic film with an angle of incidence θ. Photodiode #2 (identical to photodiode #1) then measures the quantity of reflected light. A reverse bias E≃10 V is applied to both photodiodes so that they provide voltages V 1 and V 2 proportional to the light intensities. The simultaneous measurement of the incident and the reflected intensities with two identical photodiodes removes the noise caused by the laser fluctuations. A real-time analog computational unit (AD538 from Analog Devices) outputs a voltage V out proportional to the ratio V 2/V 1, i.e., to the reflectivity R of the multilayers. In order to obtain the absolute value of the reflectivity, V out is normalized by measuring the two intensities just behind the 50:50 beamsplitter (then V out corresponds with R=1).

The engineering of thin gold films on glass samples requires an adhesion layer [27, 28] to prevent the stripping of the gold layer, even if a recent process avoids this absorbing layer [29]. The SPR in gold is known to be highly sensitive to the above medium [30, 31]. This sensitivity is exploited to produce sensors for the detection of molecules in biomedicine [21, 32, 33]. In the present case a SiO2 layer is deposited on the active part of the sensor. Therefore, the sample consists of three different layers deposited by e-beam evaporation. A thin (between 1 and 2 nm) chromium layer is first deposited as an adhesion layer on a glass substrate (a 500 μm thick microscope slide which has been previously cleaned, rinsed, and dried). Next a gold film is deposited by evaporation (from 0.1 to 0.2 nm/s under 10−6 mBar): its optimum thickness is 50 nm. The maximum uncertainties of the thickness of gold can be evaluated to ±2 nm. Finally, a 10±2 nm thick SiO2 layer is deposited from granules of fused silica. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements of roughness give an average roughness of 0.6 nm and a root mean square equal to 0.75 nm.

The plasmon momentum greatly depends on the metallic film characteristics and on the properties of the media on each side of the film (index, thickness, etc.) [27, 34]. The solution of the inverse problem is tricky, and the PSO method can be of great help to retrieve different parameters from the experimental data. A model must be used to describe the experimental SPR setup. According to the small roughness of the sample, a model of interaction between light and plane multilayers is used.

Section2.Heading: The multilayer model
Section2.Para:
The classical model of a plane multilayer proposed in [23, 27, 28] is commonly used when the roughness of layers is negligible due to the process of deposition. Figure 2 shows the parameters and marking of the model. The model takes advantage of being a direct generalization of the Fresnel coefficients to multilayers [35–38]. The generalized Fresnel coefficients can be calculated for multilayers as follows.

The interfaces between linear and homogeneous media are identified by planes z=const. The material layer is infinite in the (x,y) directions, and therefore the problem is called one dimensional (only one coordinate is necessary to define the geometry).

The illumination wave vector is k
i =(u,0,−w 1) (the z-component w 1 should not be confused with the angular frequency ω of the monochromatic waves in all linear and isotropic materials). The x-component of the wave vector depends on the angle of incidence θ through
$u = k_{0} \sqrt{\epsilon_{1}} \sin(\theta)$ where ϵ 1 is the permittivity of the medium of incidence. The monochromatic plane waves are solutions of the Helmholtz equation, and therefore the components of the wave vectors in each medium i (with relative permittivity ϵ
i ) verify:
1
$$ u^2 + w_i^2 = k_0^2 \epsilon_i = \frac{\omega^2}{c^2} \epsilon_i. $$

Because the illumination is linearly polarized, the full vectorial problem is reduced to scalar. The magnetic field lies along the y axis, in the plane (x,y) of each interface between materials, if a single (p) polarized monochromatic wave impinges on the multilayers. The angular frequency of the monochromatic illumination ω and the speed of light in a vacuum c are related to the angular wavenumber k 0=ω/c=2π/λ 0 where λ 0 is the wavelength in a vacuum.

The Fourier transform of the Maxwell equations and the boundary conditions gives a set of linear equations between amplitudes of the monochromatic plane waves in each medium. This linear system of equations has to be solved to find the amplitudes of electromagnetic fields in each medium [25, 39, 40]. At each interface, the continuity of the magnetic field (in (p) polarization) and of the z-component of the product of the permittivity by the electric field gives a scalar problem that can be solved easily, giving the generalized Fresnel coefficients. Figure 2 shows the four unknown amplitudes for two interfaces and three media. If an additional layer with relative permittivity ϵ
i is considered in the model, two supplementary unknowns are introduced (the up and down fields in this layer). Two additional independent equations are therefore included in the linear system that must be solved. This supplementary layer is between the interfaces located at z

The reflectance coefficient r 13 by a single layer assuming a harmonic plane polarized wave incoming on the material setup illustrates the use of surface plasmon resonance in SPR biosensors [25] when an adhesion layer between gold and the subtrate is used. The relative reflected intensity considering five media and four parallel interfaces requires more calculation efforts for solving a linear system of ten equations. The positions of each interface can be expressed as functions of the thickness of layers e

Returning to the experiment (Fig. 1), it is also necessary to introduce a correction factor C of the reflectance R from the transmission from air to BK7 (ϵ
B , w
B ), from BK7 to the microscope slide (ϵ 1, w 1), and in reverse from the microscope slide to BK7 and from BK7 to the air. It is deduced from the transmission Fresnel coefficients in (p) polarization under normal incidence:
8
$$ C = 16 \frac{\sqrt{\epsilon_B}}{(1+ \sqrt{\epsilon_B})^2} \frac{\epsilon_B \epsilon_1 w_1 w_B}{(\epsilon_B w_1+\epsilon_1 w_B)^2}. $$

This model is used to retrieve the unknown experimental parameters (also called decision parameters, as opposed to parameters that are supposed to be known) from the fitting of experimental curves. The nine parameters are the thicknesses of the three layers and their complex number relative permittivities. The number of unknowns precludes a systematic search for nested loops in a reasonable computational time and therefore a heuristic search is advisable.

The target of fitting is the experimental reflectance f ref=R(θ) recorded for green (λ 0=543 nm) and red (λ 0=633 nm) wavelengths (Eq. (9)). The second measurement is used to check the repeatability of the measurement of thicknesses.

Section2.Heading: The particle swarm method
Section2.Para:
The principle of optimization methods is to find the decision parameters x(t
a ) for a given target: the minimum of F(x), the fitness function of x, at algorithm step t
a . The parameters are searched in a domain D of dimension dim(D). x(t
a ) is therefore a vector of size dim(D). The metaheuristic methods require a family of N
S vectors x(t
a ) (
$x_{1..N_{S}}(t)$ ), which is the swarm of particles. This swarm investigates the domain of search of decision parameters. Consequently, x(t
a ) can be stored as a matrix of size dim(D)×N
S .

If the goal is finding the variables for which the minimum of the model |f(x)| is reached, then f ref=0 in Eq. (9) (the reference is 0), and the problem corresponds to the optimization of the system which is described by the model.

For both data fitting and inverse problem resolution, the reference comes from measurements, and the target is the minimization of the distance of the model to the reference. For example, in Ref. [41] the challenge was to retrieve the unknown experimental parameters from the measurement of the reflectance R of a thin aluminum layer deposited on a glass prism [42]. The same objective was pursued in [43] but with another fascinating evolutionary procedure using recombination, mutation, and selection.

Therefore, the ultimate goal of the method is to find the global minimum of the fitness function F within the domain of search. Practically, the fitness function measures the distance between a reference f ref and the computed data f(x) from the model. Therefore, F is a performance indicator of the particle which is a set of inputs for the model f. For each particle x
n in the swarm
$x_{1..N_{S}}(t_{a})$ :
9
$$ F = \sqrt{\frac{1}{N_{\mathrm{ref}}} {\sum \limits _{m=1}^{m=N_{\mathrm{ref}}} \bigl|f(x_n) - f_{\mathrm{ref}}\bigr|^2}}. $$ The finite number of references f ref is N ref, and the fitness function is the standard deviation of the fit compared to the reference. Minimizing F corresponds to a search of the model inputs that correspond to the mean square fit of f ref. The fitness function can also be defined as the maximum of the correlation of f(x
n ) and f ref. The reader can verify that results are close together by using some numerical experiences.

The particle swarm optimization (PSO) method is classically used for optimization of complex systems [44]. This method was proposed by Kennedy and Eberhart [45]. The decision variable x mimics the behavior of a swarm of bees in search of pollen, in a domain of search. The position of the pollen corresponds to the minimum of a fitness function. Therefore, this metaheuristic method can be easily illustrated by movies showing the search for the optimum in simple problems. Plotting the evolution of decision variables converging to the optimum of a simple function in a 2D search space gives a practical insight into the method.

Another point of view is closely related to physics. Any input of the model (or possible parameters, or decision variables) forms a vector x(t
a ) whose size depends on the degree of freedom of the model. This vector corresponds to a particle which moves randomly in the search domain to fall into a potential well. Each particle communicates good positions to each other particle and adjusts its own position x(t
a ) and velocity V(t
a ) based on these best positions following
10
$$\begin{aligned} V(t_a+1) = & \omega_{\mathrm{PSO}} V(t_a) + U_1 c_1 \bigl(p(t_a) - x(t_a) \bigr) \\ &{}+ U_2 c_2 \bigl(g(t_a) - x(t_a)\bigr), \end{aligned}$$
11
$$\begin{aligned} x(t_a+1) =& x(t_a)+ \bigl((t_a+1)-t_a \bigr) V(t_a+1) \\ =& x(t_a)+ V(t_a+1), \end{aligned}$$ where U
i (i=1,2) are independent pseudo-random uniform variables between 0 and 1, p(t
a ) is the particle best position in its own history, g(t
a ) is the global best over all the previous steps, ω PSO is the inertial weight, and c 1 and c 2 are the acceleration coefficients. The iteration step t
a being integer, Eq. (11) is a finite difference expression of the velocity. Therefore, t
a can be called “time” and is directly related to the execution time of the algorithm.

The proposed PSO Algorithm 1 (detailed in Appendix) is one of the simplest ones, where exogenous parameters of the PSO method are fixed after a numerical preliminary study: N
S =30, fixed acceleration coefficients c 1=c 2=2, and a linear decrease of the inertial weight ω from 0.9 to 0.4 from step 1 to t max [47]. As mentioned in a previous study [48], the results are hardly dependent on the three parameters (c 1 c 2, N
S ). t max is the termination criterion of the algorithm, which has to be fixed after some preliminary tests as a compromise between the expected convergence towards the minimum and the acceptable duration of the calculation. It has been varied from 102 to 106 in the preliminary computations. A fair compromise between accuracy of the solution and computational time is chosen in each case. To convince himself, the reader can try values of these parameters as described in Ref. [49]. Algorithm 1 in Appendix is written as pseudo-code and could help the reader to build a program in any computational language.

The investigated problem is the fit of experimental curves of reflectance by a gold layer to deduce unknown experimental parameters, in other words, to solve the inverse problem, in a reasonable time.

Section1.Heading: The inverse problem for the SPR angular inspection of the multilayers
Section1.Para: The optical index of thin metal plates is known to be a function of the layer thickness and of the deposition parameters [5, 15] and sometimes oxidation [41]. The discrepancies between measured data [53–57] for gold material are seldom underlined. For instance, the websites [58, 59] give two different values for the optical index of gold at wavelength 633 nm; the corresponding relative permittivities are −10.9824+1.3280ı and −9.5142+1.2178ı, where ı 2=−1. The model should be as realistic as possible; therefore, the multilayer model includes the sample, the adhesion layer, the gold plate, the SiO2 protection layer, and the surrounding medium (air).

Consequently, the fixed parameters in the model are the relative permittivities of the dielectric materials: the above medium (air ϵ 5=1), the SiO2 layer ϵ 4=2.1324@543 nm and ϵ 4=2.1231@633 nm. The optical property of the microscope slide remains unknown. The decision parameters are the relative permittivities of the glass sample holder ϵ 1, of chromium ϵ 2 (a complex number), of gold ϵ 2 (a complex number) and the respective thicknesses of each layer, e 2 (chromium), e 3 (gold), and e 4 (SiO2 covering layer). The degree of freedom is therefore dim(D)=8, and a deterministic method of search using nested loops would require too much computational time. As an alternative, the PSO is used with a domain of search which is deduced from an a priori knowledge of the nominal values (the setpoints), but enlarged by the experimental uncertainties on thicknesses and the variations of the relative permittivities found in handbooks [57] over a wide range of wavelengths:

ϵ 1∈[2.13;2.41], {ℜ(ϵ 2);ℜ(ϵ 3)}∈[−36;36] {ℑ(ϵ 2);ℑ(ϵ 3)}∈[0;72], e 2∈[0;4] nm, e 3∈[40;55] nm, and e 4∈[0;15] nm. The zero values are included in the domain of search for the adhesion layer and the covering layer to enable us to test their respective influence on the results. The mean values of the fitness are close together for both wavelengths; therefore, the method seems to work well in the investigated domain of search. Moreover, the best solution appears to be unique despite the number of unknowns. The mean of the relative permittivity of the microscope slide is close to that of the glass. The relative permittivity is coherent with the known dispersion of glass within the visible range [58, 59].

The recovered values for chromium and gold can be compared to the relative permittivities of the bulk indicated in Tables 2 and 1 according to Ref. [57]. The relative permittivities of the thin layer can vary as a function of the deposition mode, the thickness of the metal film [5, 15], the oxidation [41], and of whether the sample is annealed or not [60]. The thin layers of chromium and gold are found to be more metallic than the bulk, but chromium remains a strongly absorbing material compared to gold. The values retrieved with the PSO method are of the same order as those of the bulk material, and the variations of both their real and imaginary parts are coherent with previous studies for silver [61]. In that paper the modification of relative permittivities of the thin layer was assigned to the monocrystalline or polycrystalline structure of nanostructured metal.

The best thickness of gold is smaller than 50 nm, which was the experimental setpoint of the elaboration of layers, but it is about the same for both wavelengths. The best thickness of the chromium layer is less than 2 nm in both cases, results that are also coherent with the nominal deposit. The thicknesses of SiO2 are close together in both cases and smaller than 10 nm. However, the standard deviation of e 4 shows that this parameter is less critical for the fit of experimental data. Figures 3 and 4 show the result of the fitting with the mean parameters indicated in Tables 1 and 2. The agreement is satisfactory; therefore, the model seems to be adapted to describe the experiments.

The wide range of search and the magnitude of standard deviations lead us to conclude that no other solutions exist in the neighborhood of the nominal values. The retrieved thicknesses are smaller than the nominal values. A likely explanation of this decay may be related to the speed of deposition (0.1 to 0.2 nm/s), which makes it difficult to accurately monitor the metal deposition process. A decay of 8 nm for the gold thickness corresponds to a reduction of time between 40 s and 80 s, i.e., only 16 % of the setpoints time of deposition and this ratio is more critical for the small deposition time of chromium and SiO2. Moreover, the films’ thicknesses can slightly vary over the whole substrate surface. Another explanation could be the roughness of deposition, but the sample was annealed to reduce it. The average roughness measured with AFM is smaller than 1 nm, and therefore it can be neglected in this case [62, 63]. The results could correspond to the mean value of the thickness of each layer. Complementary ellipsometry measurements have been driven and gave a thickness of chromium of 1.1±0.2 nm, a gold thickness equal to 47±1 nm, and a SiO2 thickness equal to 2.3±0.1 nm. These values are consistent with the PSO results deduced from the SPR experiment (taking the standard deviation into account), except for the SiO2 layer which is thinner according to the ellipsometry measurements. The permittivities used for the ellipsometric measurements fitting are deduced from tabulated values [53, 57], because using models for the permittivities like Tauc-Lorentz [64] or Drude-Lorentz [65] returns irrelevant results. Of course, the mismatch between the tabulated values and the ones calculated by PSO induces differences in the thicknesses given by both optimization algorithms. The almost opaque gold layer, the very thin chromium film, and the sensitivity of ellipsometry to the small roughness (<1 nm) of the upper layer limit the accuracy of the fitting of the ellipsometric measurements. Moreover, the results greatly depend on the starting thickness values. According to the starting thicknesses, the regression algorithm can return a local minimum and then give wrong results. All these reasons may explain the discrepancy between the expected and measured SiO2 thicknesses. The proposed method of direct measurement of thicknesses and optical properties of a three-layer material settlement by fitting the angular interrogation of reflectance seems to be more efficient than classical ellipsometry. No dispersion model is required for SPR measurement. In the following section, the method is applied to samples with different thicknesses of SiO2.

Section1.Heading: Application of the method to three samples with different thicknesses of the last layer
Section1.Para: To address the reliability of the method, we finally study three samples for which the deposition of chromium, gold, and SiO2 have been carefully controlled (by sputtering and inductively coupled plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition). The deposition setpoint is 2 nm of Cr and 50 nm of Au, and the samples have been metallized at the same time in order to obtain exactly the same metal thicknesses. Therefore, the expected values of recovered metal thicknesses and optical properties should also be the same, in contrast to the thickness of the SiO2 layer. The deposition setpoints of the SiO2 layer are, respectively, 10 nm (sample S 10), 15 nm (S 15), and 20 nm (S 20).

In the three cases, the unknown parameters are searched within a common wide domain: ϵ 1∈[2.13;2.41], {ℜ(ϵ 2);ℜ(ϵ 3)}∈[−36;36], {ℑ(ϵ 2);ℑ(ϵ 3)}∈[0;72], e 2∈[0;4] nm, e 3∈[40;55] nm, and e 4∈[5;25] nm. The results of the resolution of the inverse problem are shown in Tables 3, 4 and 5.

Tables 3 and 4 reveal a dispersion of values for the optical properties of chromium and a good agreement between the optical properties of the substrate and of gold. Therefore, the optical properties of the thin layer of chromium are not critical for the inverse problem in this case [27, 28]. The same conclusion was drawn in Sect. 4. In contrast, the results for gold are comparable to those in Tables 1 and 2. The fitness function is of comparable order of magnitude in the three cases. The recovered thicknesses are summarized in Table 5 for both wavelengths for comparison.

The recovered thicknesses are consistent with each other and are closer to the deposition setpoints than the ellipsometric measurements: 4 nm, 10 nm, and 12 nm for SiO2, 2 nm for the Cr layer, and 40 nm for the gold layer. This decay between the results is again explained by the optical constants of the deposited layer of gold which differs strongly from the nominal values of the bulk used for ellipsometry (reference data in Tables 1 and 2). The results of the inverse problem show that the recovered thicknesses of gold are a little bit smaller than the setpoints as in Sect. 4. The thickness of chromium is close to the setpoint and that of SiO2 suffers from uncertainty, but its mean value is not so far from the setpoint. The inverse problem gives better results than ellipsometry for the last sample (setpoint e 4=20 nm). Assuming that the uncertainty on decision parameters is defined as the standard deviation of the solutions of the inverse problem, the intervals of uncertainties of the recovered parameters intersect.

A basic study of the sensitivity of the model (Eq. (5)) to each parameter can be evaluated by computing the cross-correlation of the fitness function with the parameter [30]. The result is dimensionless using normalization so that the auto-correlations of data at zero lag are identically 1. All results of realizations of the inverse problem are used as input data for sensitivity. The sensitivity S(ϵ 1)=0.99 of the model to the optical properties of the sample holder (ϵ 1) is critical, as it governs the position of the dip in reflectance. S(e 3) is typically 0.98, while the sensitivity to the thickness of SiO2 is S(e 4)=0.96. S(ϵ 2)≈S(e 2) drops to 0.94 for the chromium layer. These results are encouraging for the measurement of the thickness of any medium above gold, and cause us to conclude that the quality of the gold deposition should be carefully controlled.

The PSO method thus seems to be efficient to recover thicknesses and optical properties of a three-layer medium. The recovered values of the optical constants are close together for the three samples at each wavelength.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: The purpose of this study was to measure the thickness and optical properties of multilayers with an SPR setup. To achieve this goal a multilayer model is proposed to handle the various materials involved in the experimental setup, the particle swarm optimization (PSO) method is detailed, and a pseudo-algorithm is given. The PSO is used for solving the inverse problem of the angular investigation of reflectance by multilayers, measured from surface plasmon resonance. The optical properties of the bulk materials are shown to be inadequate for thin layers [43]. The PSO method is a simple and efficient method for solving the inverse problem as well as for the optimization of complex systems in engineering [44]. The propagation of uncertainties or tolerance studies [46, 66] also benefit from this method, and using more complex electromagnetism models [67] can extend the domain of its application. The proposed method can probably be generalized to any problem of characterization of multilayers—this quite specific example of resolution of the inverse problem is not restrictive. SPR is widely used for chemical sensors and SPO can be very helpful in characterizing the adsorbed layer (which the top SiO2 layer mimics in our experiment) but also the different layers, whose properties are fundamental for calibrating the sensor with accuracy.
